Datastructures.Theory

Class DisjointnessClasses

  • java.lang.Object
    • Datastructures.Theory.DisjointnessClasses

  • public class DisjointnessClasses
extends java.lang.Object
    A disjointness class is a set of literals which are pairwise contradictory. Such a class may come from the input data, or be derived from ID_Implications. Created by Ohlbach on 21.09.2018.

      • initialize

        private void initialize()
        initialises the classes at first usage.

      • addDisjointnessClass

        public Clause addDisjointnessClass(int[] basicClause)
        turns a basicClause into a disjointness class.
        A true literal causes all other literals to become false
        A false literal is ignored
        Two true literals are a contradiction
        p <=> -p is ignored.
        A double literal p,p is a contradiction.
        The corresponding observers are called. New disjunctions which are subsets of a new clause are deleted. Literals occurring in several classes may cause joining of the classes.
        Parameters:
        basicClause - [clause-problemId,typenumber,literal1,...]
        Returns:
        the result disjointness clause or null

      • addDisjointness

        public void addDisjointness(int literal1,
                            int literal2)
        joins a new disjointness p disjoint q.
        Parameters:
        literal1 - a literal
        literal2 - a literal

      • addToExisting

        private boolean addToExisting(int literal1,
                              int literal2)
        tries to join two disjoint literals to existing disjointness classes.
        Parameters:
        literal1 - a literal
        literal2 - a literal
        Returns:
        true if a class has been found.

      • addToExisting

        private boolean addToExisting(Clause disjointness,
                              int literal)
        checks whether all literals in the disjointness class are disjoint with the new literal. If p is in the clause and r is the new literal, then p -> -r must hold to ensure disjointness.
        If the class is extended then it may subsume older disjunctions, and it may merge with older disjunctions.
        Parameters:
        disjointness - an existing disjointness class
        literal - a literal
        Returns:
        true if all literals in the class are´disjoint with the new literal.

      • subsume

        private void subsume(Clause disjointness)
        removes all disjunctions which are subsets of the given clause. I p,q,r are disjoint then p,q and p,r and q,r are also disjoint.
        Parameters:
        disjointness - a disjointness clause.

      • joinClauses

        private Clause joinClauses(Clause disjointness)
        joins disjointness classes if possible. It collects all literals in all disjunctions containing any of the literals in the given clause. Only those literals which are mutually disjoint are then inserted in a new clause
        Parameters:
        disjointness - a disjointness class
        Returns:
        the old or a new disjointness class

      • literalUnion

        private java.lang.Object[] literalUnion(Clause clause)
        collects all literals in all disjunctions containing one of the literals in the given clause.
        Parameters:
        clause - a disjointness clause
        Returns:
        all literals in all disjunctions containing one of the literals in the given clause.

        Parameters:

        literal2 - a literal
        Returns:

      • reportUnsatisfiable

        private void reportUnsatisfiable(int literal1,
                                 int literal2)
        calls all unsatisfiabilityObservers with an Unsatisfiable object. This may be caused by an equivalence p = -p
        Parameters:
        literal1 - a literal
        literal2 - its negation.
